revisions.rev:
{{ NCAATeamSeason | Mode = football | Year = 1972 | Team = Nebraska Cornhuskers | Logo = University-of-Nebraska-Lincoln-logo.svg | LogoSize = 59 | Image = | ImageSize = | ImageAlt = | Conference = Big Eight Conference | Division = | ShortConference = Big 8 | BCSRank = | CoachRank = 9 | APRank = 4 | Record = 9-2-1 | ConfRecord = 5-1-1 | WinsVacated = | WinsForfeited = | ConfWinsVacated = | ConfWinsForfeited = | HeadCoach = [[Bob Devaney]] | HCYear = 11th | OffCoach = [[Tom Osborne]] | OCYear = 4th | DefCoach = | DCYear = | OScheme = [[I formation]] | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] | Champion = Big 8 Champions
Orange Bowl Champions | BowlTourney = [[1973 Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]] vs. #12 {{cfb link|year=1972|school=University of Notre Dame|team=Notre Dame Fighting Irish|title=Notre Dame}} | BowlTourneyResult = W 40-6 | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1972 Big 8 football standings}} The '''1972 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' represented the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1972 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[Bob Devaney]] and played their home games in [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska|Lincoln]]. ==Schedule== {{Cite web |url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1972 |title =Football - 1972 Schedule/Results |accessdate=2009-06-17 |publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln Athletics Department}} {{CFB Schedule Start|rankyear=1972|tv=|attend=yes}} {{CFB Schedule Entry | w/l = l | date = September 9 | nonconf = yes | homecoming = | time = | rank = 1 | away = yes | neutral = | opprank = | opponent = {{cfb link|year=1972|school=University of California, Los Angeles|team=UCLA Bruins|title=UCLA}} | site_stadium = [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum|L.A. in this position''' ||align="center"|'''Years at Nebraska''' ||align="left"|'''Alma Mater''' |- |'''[[Bob Devaney]]'''|||[[Head Coach]]||align="center"|1962||align="center"|1962-72||[[Alma Ross'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1962-76|| |- |'''John Melton'''|||Tight Ends, Wingbacks||align="center"|1973||align="center"|1962-88||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |- |'''Mike Corgan'''|||Running Backs||align="center"|1962||align="center"|1962-82||[[University of Notre Dame|Notre Dame]] |- |'''[[Monte Kiffin]]'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1967-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''[[Warren Powers]]'''|||Defensive Backs||align="center"| ||align="center"|1969-76||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''Boyd Epley'''|||Head Strength Coach||align="center"|1969||align="center"|1969â2003||[[University of NebraskaâLincoln|Nebraska]] |- |'''[[Jim Walden]]'''||| ||align="center"| ||align="center"|1971-72||[[University of Wyoming|Wyoming]] |- |'''Bill Myles'''|||Offensive Line||align="center"|1972||align="center"|1972-76|| |} ==Game notes== ===UCLA=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#1 Nebraska at UCLA''' [box score] | Visitor = #1 Nebraska | Host = '''{{cfb link|year=1972|school=University of California, Los Angeles|team=UCLA Bruins|title=UCLA}}''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 10| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 3| H2 = 7| H3 = 7| H4 = 3 | Date = 1972-09-09 | Location = [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]], [[Los Angeles, California]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 67,702 }} {{AFB game box end}} Unranked [[UCLA Bruins football|UCLA]], sporting their new wishbone offense led by [[Mark Harmon]], handed #1 Nebraska its first loss in 33 games, and broke Nebraska's 23-game winning streak, both at that time active NCAA records. The Cornhuskers were upset in [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum|Los Angeles]] after suffering four fumbles and giving up two interceptions, though the game was not decided until UCLA's [[Efren Herrera]] kicked a field goal with just 22 seconds remaining in the game. {{-}} ===Texas A&M=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Texas A&M at #10 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1972|school=Texas A&M University|team=Texas A&M Aggies|title=Texas A&M}} | Host = '''#10 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 14| H2 = 7| H3 = 7| H4 = 9 | Date = 1972-09-16 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,042 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska owned the game and had little difficulty with Texas A&M, whose sole touchdown came late in the 4th quarter against Cornhusker reserves. {{-}} ===Army=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#9 Nebraska at Army''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#9 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1972|school=United States Military Academy|team=Army Black Knights|title=Army}} | V1 = 14| V2 = 21| V3 = 28| V4 = 14 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 7 | Date = 1972-09-23 | Location = [[Michie Stadium]], [[West Point, New York]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 42,239 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska entirely stomped Army, with the Cornhusker reserves taking over in the 3rd quarter behind a very comfortable lead, and the Black Knights' lone score to prevent the shutout came on a 10 yard pass reception with just 35 seconds left to play. {{-}} ===Minnesota=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Minnesota at #7 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1972 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] | Host = '''#7 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 21| H3 = 14| H4 = 7 | Date = 1972-09-30 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,217 }} {{AFB game box end}} For the third straight week, Nebraska dominated the game in every way, shutting out Minnesota while piling up 542 yards of offense. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Missouri at #6 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1972|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}} | Host = '''#6 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 7| H2 = 14| H3 = 27| H4 = 14 | Date = 1972-10-14 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,511 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska was not affected by the week off, and thoroughly pounded Missouri 62-0. Although the scoreboard and statistics might suggest Missouri was out of their league against Nebraska, the Tigers went on after this painful shutout to upset Notre Dame and Colorado in their next two games. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#5 Nebraska at Kansas''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#5 Nebraska''' | Host = {{cfb link|year=1972|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | V1 = 0| V2 = 28| V3 = 14| V4 = 14 | H1 = 0| H2 = 0| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1972-10-21 | Location = [[University of Kansas Memorial Stadium|McCook Field]], [[Lawrence, Kansas]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 50,500 }} {{AFB game box end}} The shutouts and domination continued, as Nebraska scored at will against Kansas in Lawrence, and held the Jayhawks to just 63 total yards of offense and only 4 1st downs. {{-}} ===Oklahoma State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Oklahoma State at #3 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = {{cfb link|year=1972|school=Oklahoma State University-Stillwater|team=Oklahoma State Cowboys|title=Oklahoma State}} | Host = '''#3 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 0 | H1 = 13| H2 = 0| H3 = 7| H4 = 14 | Date = 1972-10-28 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,432 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska tied a 1937 NCAA record of 4 straight shutouts, and although Oklahoma State was not as easy to push around as the previous three opponents, the Cornhuskers still had little trouble getting the win. {{-}} ===Colorado=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#3 Nebraska at #15 Colorado''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#3 Nebraska''' | Host = #15 {{cfb link|year=1972|school=University of Colorado at Boulder|team=Colorado Buffaloes|title=Colorado}} | V1 = 19| V2 = 0| V3 = 14| V4 = 0 | H1 = 0| H2 = 10| H3 = 0| H4 = 0 | Date = 1972-11-04 | Location = [[Folsom Field]], [[Boulder, Colorado]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 52,128 }} {{AFB game box end}} Colorado attempted to put some more challenge into the event than Nebraska had been seeing in recent games, and was even able to draw back from a 0-19 deficit to get within 9 by halftime and end Nebraska's shutout streak, but it was all Cornhusker points the rest of the way. Still, the [[Blackshirts (football)|Blackshirts]] mourned the end of their touchdown-free stretch at 17 quarters. {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#3 Nebraska at #17 Iowa State''' [box score] | Visitor = #3 Nebraska | Host = #17 {{cfb link|year=1972|school=Iowa State University|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | V1 = 7| V2 = 6| V3 = 0| V4 = 10 | H1 = 0| H2 = 10| H3 = 7| H4 = 6 | Date = 1972-11-11 | Location = Clyde Williams Field, [[Ames, Iowa]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 36,231 }} {{AFB game box end}} Iowa State pretty much ended any Nebraska hopes for another national title, as the Cornhuskers gave up two interceptions and six fumbles to help the Cyclones stay in the game. Nebraska came back from behind to pull ahead 20-17 in the 4th, and padded the lead with a field goal when the clock was down to just 1:03, but Iowa State stormed back down the field to score again with 0:23 remaining, and would have won the game outright if the subsequent PAT had not failed and ended the game tied at 23. {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''Kansas State at #5 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = [[1972 Kansas State Wildcats football team|Kansas State]] | Host = '''#5 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 7 | H1 = 10| H2 = 28| H3 = 14| H4 = 7 | Date = 1972-11-18 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 75,079 }} {{AFB game box end}} Nebraska put up Coach Devaney's 100th career win as the Cornhuskers easily trampled Kansas State in Lincoln and had reserves in the game for playing time while cruising behind a comfortable 38-0 lead even prior to the half. The Wildcats finally put up a touchdown with just over 6 minutes remaining to play. {{-}} ===Oklahoma=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#14 Oklahoma at #5 Nebraska''' [box score] | Visitor = '''#14 [[1972 Oklahoma Sooners football team|Oklahoma]]''' | Host = #5 Nebraska | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 7| V4 = 10 | H1 = 7| H2 = 0| H3 = 7| H4 = 0 | Date = 1972-11-23 | Location = [[Memorial Stadium, Lincoln|Memorial Stadium]], [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = CST | Attendance = 76,587 }} {{AFB game box end}} It looked like Nebraska's day, as the Cornhuskers led at the half and were up 14-0 in the 3rd, but Oklahoma came back to score 17 points straight for the lead and the win, ending Nebraska's home winning streak dating to 1969. {{-}} ===Notre Dame=== {{AFB game box start | Title = '''#9 Nebraska vs #12 Notre Dame''' [box score] | Visitor = #12 {{cfb link|year=1972|school=University of Notre Dame|team=Notre Dame Fighting Irish|title=Notre Dame}} | Host ='''#9 Nebraska''' | V1 = 0| V2 = 0| V3 = 0| V4 = 6 | H1 = 7| H2 = 13| H3 = 20| H4 = 0 | Date = 1973-01-01 | Location = [[Miami Orange Bowl|Orange Bowl]], [[Miami, Florida|Miami]], [[Florida]] | StartTime = | TimeZone = EST | Attendance = 80,010 }} {{AFB game box end}} [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Johnny Rodgers]] was shifted from WB to IB for the [[1973 Orange Bowl]], and flashed brilliance as he ran for three touchdowns, caught a touchdown pass, and also threw a fifth touchdown. The Cornhuskers scored with ease and often against the stunned [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Fighting Irish]], who were unable to put any points up of their own until the 4th quarter. This was head coach [[Bob Devaney]]'s final game, a third straight [[Orange Bowl (game)|Orange Bowl]] victory, and second straight Orange Bowl rout. {{-}} ==Rankings== {{See also|1972 NCAA Division I-A football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement |- ! [[Bob Wolfe]] |} ==1972 Team Players in the NFL== The 1972 Nebraska Cornhuskers seniors selected in the [[1973 NFL Draft]]:[http://www.pro-football-reference.com/draft/1973.htm Pro Football Reference.com] -
